text: A red, translucent shadow drips down a bedroom wall like rain bathing EVA KACHADOURIAN, in it’s eerie glow. Fifty years old but looking a good ten older, Eva lies in bed, eyes open, staring blankly at the ceiling. O.S. beep of a digital alarm clock. She slams her hand down on the battered clock, it’s face cracked and fixed with tape. It’s glowing red digits read 7.30AM Thursday 26th April 2001 Disoriented, she sits up and frowns, taking in the unnatu hue on her skin. Fumbling for her robe, she knocks a bottle of pills from bedside table, they scatter noisily across the floor.

Shit. She drags herself out of bed and walks over to the doorwa Feet crunching over the spilt pills. Dazed, she wanders down the hall towards the front door, squinting as she steps out into the bright morning light.

Shivering a little, she pulls her robe tight around her, walks a little way down the drive then turns to look at t building. The house looks like it’s had it’s throat slit. It’s splattered with red paint, glistening in the sunshin it drips down the woodwork. Eva surveys the scene for a moment, her face expressionl she shrugs tiredly and casually pads back into the house, closing the door behind her. FADE TO BLACK.

No, Not so sticky! Celia throws her arms round Eva’s neck. Eva smiles but her eyes are welling up. REVERSE ON CELIA; A delicate innocent face. ONE EYE BLANK LOOKING, PROSTHET stares eerily ahead. Eva extricates herself from Celia’s tight hug and turns b to the stove brushing her eyes.
Now... eat your breakfast honey.
Daddy!.. FRANKLIN (Good looking, muscular 40’s) bounds into the kitchen in a buoyant mood. He kisses the top of Celia’s h and whistling, heads for the coffee pot.

Sorry...
That’s OK. She smiles at him, shy, girlish.
You’re in a good mood...
(boyishly embarrassed) And you know why... He gives her a quick peck on the cheek and is about to tu back to the table when Eva pulls him closer and kisses hi deeply.
Gross... KEVIN (15) sidles into the kitchen, dressed in a smart wh fencing shirt and black slacks.
Oh... you’re up. Eva and Franklin pull apart, almost guiltily, like a coup of teenagers caught at it.
Looking good...
Wow, what happened... were all your size one clothes in the wash?
Some days you just wake up with a sense of occasion. Kevin tucks the billowing shirt neatly into his pants.
Kevin looks handsome. He does look handsome and Eva looks at him with a hint of pride.

Yup... your brother’s a heartbreaker... Now don’t dawdle, You’re supposed to eat it, not make friends with it. Kevin plonks his open rucksack on the table with a clunk It’s full of heavy yellow Kryptonite bike locks.
See you’ve got some takers...

Right...

(trying again) That reminds me we should shoot a roll of you at archery practice sometime soon.... Capture that steely gaze and steady arm for posterity... Franklin slaps Kevin on the back. It’s a mistake Kevin flinches, his mask falls and for a split second Eva notic look of ‘revulsion’?
Yeah Dad. That would be...great.
(seemingly oblivious to Kevin’s disinterest) ‘course I’d have to shoot it on a long lens... you see the only way to capture...

(Levelly) Listen, I don’t care how your stupid camera works. I don’t want to be a location scout for a bunch of crappy products. I’m not interested. I don’t want to play Frisbee in the back yard or one more game of monopoly with a candy ass one eyed midget. And I’ve had it up to my eyeballs with heart-to- heart father-son talks about aspects of my life that are none of your business. Franklin looks stunned, flushed with a tinge of anger. Ev meets his eyes and just perceptibly shakes her head. He silently starts to fit his lenses back in the case.

Can you pass the sugar please? Franklin slides the sugar in Kevin’s direction. Kevin sta to heap a disgusting amount over his breakfast. An uncomfortable silence. No one makes eye contact, like polite people pretending they didn’t notice a very loud f Franklin studies the newspaper he’s already read, and Eva gathers up her purse and some paperwork.
OK, time to make a move. She bends to kiss Celia’s head, brushing a last speck of crust from her eyelash. Celia stands woodenly her arms held out.
I’1ll miss you... Eva glances at her watch.

(noncommittally) Don’t know, might be tied up... Eva shrugs and picks up her bag, kissing Franklin briefly the cheek as she passes on her way to the door.

Eva’s stockinged feet up on the desk, viewed from behind, swivels on the chair, the phone pressed to her ear...

A strange lull as Eva speeds past rows of white picket fe houses and neat manicured lawns. No one around. Two wild looking dogs pull trash from an upturned can, snarling and showing their teeth.

Red and blue sirens pulse eerily from emergency vehicles Eva stumbles through the lot towards the school. CLOSELY FOLLOWING EVA; Everything slows to a strange half speed, as if underwate Total chaos. A mass of half-naked teenage bodies writhe together, pile top of one another, screaming and yelling, covered in a viscous, blood-red liquid. Is this hell? SPLAT. Bedrooms... bearable, plumbing... practically non-existent. She clicks it off with a sigh and casts her eyes round th drab, bare room... something lonely about her. She sighs turns on her side her gaze fixing on the phone.

huh... well half a shower. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) So you're naked? 12. She laughs and twirls round, dropping the towel, admiring toned body in the mirror.

Eva’s car squeals to a halt, she leaps out looking pale a desperate. She runs up the steps into the hospital buildi

The same hospital corridor where Eva waited for Kevin wit his broken arm. The same green plastic chairs. Eva and Franklin sit in a heavy silence, clutching each others hand tightly. A coffee with a crinkled skin sits s on the table. A surgeon approaches with a sombre expression. Eva and Franklin stand up.
I’m sorry, we really tried but there was too much damage, I'm afraid we couldn’t save the eye...
The engine’s running just to get the heating going, Eva s shivering without a coat. An empty silence. Franklin knocks his head back against the padded headrest stares at the ceiling.
I can’t believe you left it out. Eva looks at him stunned.
I thought about not saying that. She licks her lips and starts to tremble.
I didn’t leave it out. Franklin drops his head and sighs.  120.
Eva. Don’t make me do this. You used that ‘Liquid Plumr’ on Saturday, I remember because you went on about how the drain smelled weird or something.
I put it away, back in that high cabinet with the child lock on it. Celia couldn’t even reach that with a chair!...
Then how did it get out?
Good question.
Look, I realize you’re usually very caref...
I remember putting it away Franklin.
Do you remember putting on your shoes this morning?
Celie’s in hospital why are we having this conversation?
Because I want you to admit it...
Janis came this morning, maybe...
She didn’t need it, the drains were already clear...
(she’s got to say it) Fine, why don’t you ask Kevin how the bottle got left out?  121.
Here we go, something goes wrong, you can’t possibly be at fault so you point the finger at your own son.
He was supposed to be looking after her...

Kevin did everything he should have. He said when she started to scream, he came running and when he found out what it was, he ran water over her face and rinsed her eye as best he could, and then he called an ambulance, even before he called me on the cell...He was a star.
Time...it takes time for that stuff to work. Maybe he did wash it out, but when? When he was finished?
Finished with what? His homework? His archery practice?
Think about it! Eva starts to cry, she presses her finger tips to her eyelids.

She’s seven, not two. Even if I did leave it out.. Why the hell would Celia pour drain cleaner on her own eye. Celia’s afraid of everything. He did it Franklin... oh he did it, he did it! Franklin grabs her arms, looks her in the eye.
That’s enough. I’m ashamed of you... She wrenches herself free, grabs the handle of the door, has to get out. She stumbles towards her car.  122.
Eva! Eva turns round, tears streaming down her face.

You know I’m not usually big on shrinks but maybe you should talk to somebody. I think you need help. Eva turns and hurries off to her car; arms clutched aroun her protectively. Franklin’s 4x4 squeals out of the lot behind her.
Eva drives down a lonely, barely lit highway, the tears h stopped now... she’s just blank.
Franklin with his head in his hands on the sofa, Eva froz in the armchair across from him.
I’m sorry Eva, I can take the years...I just can’t take the days.
So...what do you want to do?
Last out the school year if we can. Make arrangements over the summer. At least custody is a no brainer.
Is it...You’ve decided?

(limply) There’s nothing left to decide. It's already happened. Eva notices a shadow cross the hall, Kevin steps into the light. For the first time he stands up straight instead o slouching, he looks older.
-.-need a drink of water.  123.
Kev...don’t take anything you might have overheard to heart. It’s easy to misunderstand when you hear something out of context.
Why would I not know the context? He takes a single hard swallow and puts the glass back on counter.

I am the context. He turns and leaves the room. INT. LIVING ROOM- NIGHT - WEEKS LATER. Celia is sprawled asleep in the crook of Franklin’s arm o the sofa. On the left side of her face is a flesh colored stick on eye patch. Kevin is sat beside him watching ‘My Granny had my boyfriend's baby’ on the Jerry Springer show. Eva carefully lifts Celia out of Franklin’s arms. INT. CELIA’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Celia is awake as Eva slips her into bed.
Celie... when you got hurt? Celia nods solemnly.
What happened?
(sleepily) I got something in my eye...Kevin helped me wash it out. She turns her head away as if to end the conversation. Eva kisses her and heads towards the door.
Mommy !  124. She has covered up her good eye with her hand, then uncov it quickly.
Peek a boo! Eva’s smiles at her but her eyes fill with tears as she closes the door.
Eva is sat on the sofa, she glances up as Kevin strides i the room, the distinct shape of his archery bag draped ov his shoulder, he’s followed by Franklin.
Dad Prozac’s not that big a deal Half the kid’s in my school are on some kind of anti-depressant. Eva sighs and rubs her hand through her hair, she looks stressed and guilty.

Something came for you. She nods toward the large Fed Ex package on the floor. Ke sullies towards it and starts to rip it open with Frankli car keys. He pulls a bright yellow kryptonite bike lock out of the along with a spray of Styrofoam beans as Eva eyes him suspiciously.
What’s that for? You don’t even ride your bike.. Franklin walks back into the room holding a beer as Kevin pulls out another identical lock.
Got these for a song off the net... I thought I’d make a bundle selling them at school... Franklin pulls the remote off the coffee table, flopping on the sofa next to Eva and switching on the TV.
Good to see someone inherited your business sense huh?  125.

(dryly) Glad to see you’re being so entrepreneurial... INT. BEDROOM - NIGHT. 0.S. Franklin singing tunelessly over the thud of the sho Eva, undresses slowly, she smiles to herself a little sad and gets into bed. She peers over the quilt and watches Franklin through the open door of the en suite. He steps out of the shower and his body flits in and out view, reflected in the mirrors, still fit and athletic. He switches the bathroom light off and gets into bed. Dark, apart from the hypnotic flashing light of the digit clock. RED/BLACK. RED/BLACK. They both lie silent, awake. What more is there to say? He reaches out for her hand and pulls her towards him, kissing her tenderly on the forehead, then more deeply, h moves on top of her. The clock flashes, red black, red black. CUT TO BLACK.

text: A door swings open, revealing Celia playing with her Fren toast at the table, behind her Eva in Franklin’s arms exchanging a brief kiss.

Gross...  126. INT. KITCHEN - LATER. Kevin picks up his school bag and archery kit swings them over his shoulder and leaves the house, closing the door behind him. O.S. The radio still playing...a new song comes on; Charl ‘I've been to paradise’... The music continues over the following sequence...no other sound.

Hey lady, you lady, cursing at your life... It’s a beautiful day as Kevin saunters along the neat manicured tree lined street with an air of confidence. He looks handsome as the wind blows through his hair, his sh billows, he looks every inch the a promising young man... ‘Your a disconted mother and a regimented wife’
A pretty girl glances at Kevin as he holds his arm in the in answer to the teacher’s question.
“I've no doubt you dream about the things you'll never do The corridors are full of students. Kevin pulls a handful envelopes from his bag and posts them into labelled pigeo holes on the wall.
But I wish someone had a talked to meet, like I wanna tal you... Kids pile out, laughing and chatting, full of energy. Kev sidles off towards the gym.
B.C.U. Kevin’s hands as he fixes one of the huge yellow l to the double doors of the gym.  127.

Kevin checks the door again and walks across the empty fl of the gym. A lone basketball sits in a corner he picks i and turns in one movement, shoots a perfect hoop... that was all net. INT. VIEWING GALLERY - HIGH UP IN GYM. “I've run out of places and friendly faces because I need be free”... Kevin's face, handsome and focussed, the best we’ve ever him as he fits arrow after arrow into his crossbow and fi again and again, their whistle and dull thunk just audibl over the music. “I've been to paradise but I've never been to me...” CLOSE UP the lone basketball is pierced by an arrow, nail it to the floor. It deflates slowly with a gentle hiss.

The gym doors burst open, they’re surrounded by police gunman, fireman and paramedics. Kevin is led out calmly i the circus. Helicopters swoop over head, red and blue flashing lights illuminate the dusk sky. Parents teachers and others crowd round in awe, being hel back by more police and barricades. Eva's taut, pale face as she struggles through the crowds Kevin now handcuffed, is escorted to a police car and sat down in the back, the door closed behind him. Suddenly, Eva's desperate face appears at the window as s cups a hand against the glass to cut out the reflection o the flashing lights.

As she stares through the glass.  128. Kevin regards her calmly, placidly searching for somethin her eyes. Whatever it is he doesn’t find it and they stare at each other silently for a moment before the car starts to pull away. One last look from Kevin through the back window, he seem pleased with himself, but he doesn’t smile. O.S. A scream, Eva turns to see Soweto Washington being wheeled out the gym, two arrows sticking out of his muscu thighs. Another gurney is wheeled out, a blanket over the body bu Laura Woolford’s expensive bracelets and hundred dollar Manicure are unmistakable on the one exposed hand. A scre from Mary Woolford as she breaks through the crowd and th herself on top of the body, sobbing uncontrollably. INT. EVA’S CAR - NIGHT Eva drives erratically, constantly hitting redial on her cell.

Franklin you son of a bitch! Tears hot with fury sting her cheeks. INT. WAITING AREA. POLICE STATION - NIGHT. Coffee cup. Plastic cup. Styrofoam coffee cup. O.S. Phones ringing, muted sobbing, distant voices. Kevin name, mispronounced. Eva, exhausted, suddenly aged, a dead look in her eyes, marooned on a black PVC sofa as people rush to and fro, blocking her from view. Her knee shakes involuntarily.

...-And see the little green and white one, that’s very rare from the days before NYPD blue... A teenage boy sits across from her staring glassily into middle distance without seeming to ever blink, his T-shir speckled with blood.  129. Clutching her stomach Eva stands. The receptionist eyes Eva coldly and nods in the directio the rest room further down the hall. There is a line. RECEPTIONIST. (without making eye contact) You’11 have to wait. Eva meekly sits back down. LATER STILL. Almost alone...a cleaner with a mop and a radio. Eva frozen in the same position on the black sofa.
Would you like to speak to your son? Eva shakes her head, desperate, almost fearful.
Then you're free to go Mrs Kachadaurian. She looks up slowly, stunned.
«+--+. I can go?

She walks into the lot, everything alien. Dazed, she wanders past her car, failing to recognize it first time down the row. Yet once she finds the car she becomes strangely calm. Sedate. Methodical. Keys. Lights. Seat belt. Windshield wipers on interval, to clear the thin mist. INT. CAR - NIGHT. Eva drives very slowly, breaking on yellow, coming to a legally complete halt at the four way stop though there i traffic. LATER, the car curves up the long drive to the house.  130. Methodically, she turns off the wipers and the lights the locks the car. She picks a leaf off the windscreen, scoops the jump rope the garage floor and hangs it carefully back on it’s hook the wall. INT. KITCHEN, HOUSE - NIGHT. Darkness. O.S. The flick of a light switch. Eva enters the kitchen. The greasy breakfast dishes haven’t been tidied, plates a juice glasses still on the counter, the answer phone blee with a ton of messages. The white muslin curtains of the garden doors drift lazily in the breeze.

Franklin?...Celia? Her own voice coming back at her unnerves her, it’s sound small and tinny. She walks through the house, flicking on lights. Nothing. She walks to the deck and looks out on the dark garden. She finds the switch for the floodlights, pausing for wha seems like an age before she flips it. The wide panorama of the garden lit up like a surreal painting. The grass and bushes a vivid green. The blue ni sky twinkling with stars as a backdrop. Celia. Splayed like a discarded rag doll, lies in the grass. A single arrow pins her tiny frame to the ground. Franklin. Stark in the glare of the floods, shafts of arrows throug his neck and upper body, a tragic expression frozen on hi face, profoundly disappointed. A pause.  131. Eva switches off the floodlights. CUT TO BLACK.

A huge woman struggles to reach into the depths of a refrigeration unit and pulls out a five litre tub of ice cream, slapping it on top of her already mountainous shop cart, piled high with groceries. Eva’s cart seems empty by comparison, a half loaf of brea and a bottle of white wine the only contents. She reaches for a carton of eggs and places them on the k seat of the cart, flipping it open to check for breakages they're all whole. O.S. The squeaky wheel of another cart turning into the aisle. Eva looks up. A woman about her age, in an outfit that ma have been fashionable ten years ago and appearing similar run down, is perusing the milk cartons, MARY WOOLFORD. Eva blanches with a look of shocked recognition, pricks o sweat dot her forehead. O.S. The sound of blood singing in her ears. She abandons her cart along with her embroidered Egyptian and wallet and dives into the next aisle.
A tin of Campbell’s soup full frame. The rushing noise in Eva’s ears getting louder. She gets herself together and manages to peer around the corner furtively, Mary has gone.
Eva unloads her meagre groceries, picks up the egg carton drops it onto the counter with revulsion, it feels sticky The young checkout girl flicks it open.  132.
Jesus, all twelve. Eva looks around distractedly... Mary had seen her after In fact she can make her out at the other end of the stor watching with an intense mixture of hatred and glee.
(slightly unhinged) I’‘1ll take them as they are.
But they’re totally...
I’1l take them as they are! She hands over her credit card.
(loudly, as if talking to the room) Khatchadourian, that’s an unusual name. Eva pauses for a moment then smiles.

(just as loudly) Yep, I’m the only one in the state. She snatches back her card and the bag containing the glo eggs and strides defiantly out of the store. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY Eva stops outside her run down, vandalized duplex. A kid with a basketball in his hand stands staring at the still-drying red paint.

Jesus. She lets out a deep sigh; she had forgotten. A man pokes his face out of a neighboring door and shouts something at the kid, who stands stock still for an insta then scoots off. His father ushers him inside and closes door.  133. Eva turns into the driveway. She goes to pick up her groceries from her car, the bag almost bursts open, the g from the eggs all over the passenger seat.

O.S. An abrasive scrubbing sound. A ladder against the white slatted wall. A watery red liquid rushes down in a sudden wash. Eva's feet appear as she descends. A stained sponge and a scrubbing brush thrown into a buck of water.

Walking down the hall, bucket in her hand. She catches a glimpse of her reflection in a mirror... al jumps in fright. A red smear over her nose. Her arms up to the elbow glistening as if she’d just carried out a bloodbath.
Scrubbing her hands in the sink. She can’t budge the thin red line that stubbornly remains under each fingernail.

The evening sun intensifies the already vivid red light i the kitchen, the strange hue makes the plain omelette sat front of Eva resemble a slab of raw meat. She stares at it, lost in thought, then she takes a bite. Reaching up she pulls a piece of shell from her mouth.

Eva pushes away her empty plate, a neat ring of pieces of eggshell round it’s rim, drains her wine glass and reache for the bottle, a line has been drawn halfway down the la and she pours herself a neat glass careful not to go over half way mark.

Eva almost catatonic on the sofa. Channel surfing. The Florida election debate is heating up and seems to be every station... she isn’t remotely interested, settles o the Montel Show. O.S. A woman weeping and the audience booing swims in and as Eva dozes off. FADE TO BLACK. ON THE SOUND TRACK...

They way I see it, the world is divided into the watchers and the watchees....There is more and more of an audience and less and less to see. Eva comes to, her face lit up by the glow of the TV in th darkness...pale and confused, she focuses on the screen w increasing horror.

People who actually do anything are a goddamned endangered species. You need us! What would you do without me, film a documentary on paint drying? What are all those folks doing.. but watching me. Don’t you think they would’ve changed the channel by now if all I’d done is get an A in Geometry. Eva mouth falls open... ON THE SCREEN; we catch a brief glimpse of Kevin’s hands he tosses and rolls something between them casually while talks.  135. The camera zooms to one corner of the bare cell, a lone photograph taped to the wall, swims into focus. It’s Eva's favorite picture, the one that went missing. Young, smiling and carefree in Amsterdam. The TV switches off abruptly. CUT TO BLACK. O.S. THE BEEP OF THE ALARM CLOCK.
BATTERED ALARM CLOCK, IT’S FACE CRACKED, BADLY REPAIRED W TAPE. IT READS... MONDAY 8TH APRIL 2001.
Eva’s feet crunch over the remains of the spilt pills, th crumbs clinging to her bare feet.

Eva, now dressed for work but still half asleep dodges a viscous pool of paint that has dripped from the porch as heads for her run-down car. INT. TRAVEL AGENT'S - DAY. A cantankerous but indistinguishable voice garbles down t line, Eva holds the phone away from her ear. She picks at something caught in her hair, pulls it out a inspects it, a dried fleck of red paint, she crumbles it the floor. Eva feels someone hovering and glances up, an over-made u women sporting a “My name is Wanda” lapel badge waits by side.
Okay, I’1l call back with the confirmation... thanks... bye.
Hey Eva...  136. She drops a huge pile of papers on Eva’s desk.
.-i need you to go through these bookings for me this afternoon...
Ummm....I can’t...I’m off this afternoon... I did tell you.

(tight lipped) Oh sure, that’s right. I forgot...well, just as soon as you can then... She drifts off. INT. EVA’S CAR - DAY A long open road. Well outside town the land is flat dust and bare. A huge, low concrete structure crouches on the horizon, surrounded by wire fencing. Eva swallows and straightens her shoulders, preparing herself.

Eva pushes a button on the wall outside the entrance, an electric buzzer sounds. She waits. O.S. The clanking of bolts. The door opens and a paunchy guard, (AL, late forties wit smattering of raised brown facial moles) raises a hand.
Hey Eva.
Hey Al.
You’re a week early ain’t ya?

I guess you could call it a special occasion...  137. Eva is led through a series of doors and corridors. She's padded down and searched with a metal detector. Eva knows routine and the guards all seem to know her. Eventually she’s shown into a waiting room by Al, the doo closed behind her. She sits in the corner of the drab, empty room. She yawns, picks up a lone, well thumbed copy of the Nati Enquirer, glances disinterestedly, then tosses it back on table and sighs. The door creaks open, an attractive young black woman pok her head timidly into the room. Eva tries to raise a smil for her but she seems anxious to avoid eye contact. She creeps in and takes a seat in the opposite corner, looking close to tears. After fidgeting restlessly for a moments she gets up, bending to pick up the solitary magazine, she glances up at Eva.
May I?

Go right ahead, but there’s not much in there... The woman manages a shy half smile and scurries back to h chair. Eva notices her hands are trembling slightly as sh struggles to turn the pages noiselessly. After a few moments she folds up the magazine and puts it down, casting her eyes around the room she notices the vending machine, standing in the corner. She inserts a few coins, types in her selection. A mechan whirring, a packet of M & M,s is pushed forward, it’s jus about to fall into the drawer below when the whirring sto the candy hangs tentatively in the air, it’s jammed - the machine goes silent. This seems too much for her, she rests her forehead again the clear plastic and lets out a low moan. Suddenly, Eva is at her side. She bends down and gives th vending machine a hearty whack with her fist, the M & M’s drop into the drawer and Eva fishes them out, handing the the black woman with a smile.  138.
Works every time, just gotta hit the right spot... The woman smiles shyly, Eva finds herself holding her han their eyes lock; strangely it’s Eva who’s eyes are fillin with tears.
Loretta Greenleaf? The woman looks round.
Take care honey. Another moment then she releases Eva’s hand and leaves wi the guard.

Hey Al, you still got something on your face... Kevin is led in. Eva notices a change in his demeanor bef he says a word. All that snide condescension and the swag have fallen away. A couple of fresh scratches on his face his knuckles grazed. He’s wearing an orange jumpsuit- it’s odd to see him wear something not only the normal size but too big for him. H looks dwarfed, confused, bereft. His eyes have shed their glaze and tunneled to the back o his head.
You don’t look happy.
Have I ever? His tone is wan.
I’m almost eighteen aren’t I. He rubs his face, something in his manner shows a glimpse his father, Eva winces.  139.
What is it, going to big school make you nervous?
(incredulously) ‘Nervous!’ Do you know anything about those places?
Well you did such a good job, tried as a minor, out of your head on prozac.. You'll be out in a couple of years... He shakes his head in dismay.
You know I saw you on TV
Oh that. He squirms with a tinge of embarrassment.
It was a while ago, you know, I was into a... a thing. He looks away from her. A pause.
Well I’m not sure about the thing but you sounded quite intelligent, now you only have to come up with something to say that isn’t...
(wryly) Horseshit?
You do know what day it is? Why they let me come and see you on a Monday?
Oh sure. It’s my anniversary.  140.
That’s right... two years, plenty of time to think about it... She leans forward in her chair slightly.
Look me in the eye and tell me why? Kevin can’t look her in the eye, his eyes shutter nervous between the floor and the blank walls.
(glumly) I used to think I knew... Now I’m not so sure. Without thinking, Eva extends her hand across the table a clasps his. Astonishingly he doesn’t pull away.
Thank you.

Listen...I made you something. A - well sort of present. He draws a dark rectangular wooden box about five inches from his pocket, polishes the oiled wood with the wad of toilet paper it’s been wrapped in. Carefully he slides the box across the table keeping two fingers on the top, the workmanship is surprisingly fine. She reaches, but he keeps his fingers on it fast.
Don’t!...I mean whatever you do. Don’t open it. Eva instinctively shrinks back. She flushes, a little shocked, a little horrified.
(in a stinging tone) I see. I thought that was one of your most treasured possessions. Why ever would you give it up?
It was like she was, sort of, looking at me all the time. It started to get spooky.  141.
She is looking at you. So is your father... every day. Kevin stares at the table, he shoves the box a little fur towards Eva, then removes his hand.
Anyway, I thought you might take this and, well maybe you know -

Bury it. Eva nods gravely and weighted by the enormity of the requ they spend the remaining minutes of the visit in a heavy leaden silence until the guard calls time. Eva rises slowly followed by Kevin. As she moves to hug him goodbye, he clings to her childis as he never had in childhood proper. He mutters something choked into the upturned collar of her coat...’I’m sorry’ She’s not sure if she’s heard him right but she takes the risk.

I’m sorry too Kevin. I’m sorry too. INT. EVA’S CAR - EARLY EVENING Empty highway, silence fills the car. Eva flicks on the radio. ‘the Remington fuzz away’.... Scrambling channels, news, talk shows, ads.... --.’an oldie but a goodie’ .---Are you lonesome tonight?... Do you miss me tonight? Neon signs reflected in the windscreen...Taco bell, Stapl Wallmart, swim over Eva's face... Does your memory stray to a bright sunny day. A church sign, a hand with a stop watch,’Lord teach me ho wait.’  142. She pulls up outside the duplex. Turns the engine off. Si in the car. Do the chairs in your parlor seem empty and bare? Later, inside. She sits on the couch dressed only in Franklin’s huge anc rock T-shirt. Absentmindedly, she pulls the material to h face.... breathes in. Her purse, half open sits waiting for her on the table, t box visible. A gulp of wine. She looks at the bottle, it’s down to the halfway mark. Fuck it, fills her glass. Do you gaze at your doorstep and picture me there? Eva, fuzzy...puts her hand out to grip the bannister. The is no bannister. A door at the end of the hall the opposite end to Eva's, room we haven’t seen before, a pause, she pushes the door open. Is your heart filled with pain, shall I come back again? A small, cell like bedroom; a neatly made, single bed. No much else, sparse and impersonal. She places the little box on a bare shelf, beside the onl book, ‘ROBIN HOOD’. Tell me dear are you.... She smooths down the bed covers, stands in the doorway fo moment. Lonesome tonight? Eva turns off the light leaving the empty room... waiting FADE TO BLACK. You know someone said that the world's a stage, and each must play a part...  143. Fate had me playing in love with you as my sweet heart... You read your lines so cleverly and never missed a cue... Now the stage is bare and I'm standing there, with emptiness all around... And if you wont come back to me, then they can bring the curtain down...
